intro: Eschscholzia graminea, commonly known as the common poppy, is a flowering plant native to the western United States. It is characterized by its erect, slender stem and narrow, grass-like leaves. The plant produces showy, bowl-shaped flowers that range in color from red to orange, typically blooming in late spring to early summer. It thrives in well-drained soils and full sunlight, often found in disturbed areas such as roadsides and fields. Eschscholzia graminea is an annual plant that plays a role in supporting pollinators and is sometimes cultivated for its ornamental value.
